5.text:
Whether it is with an investment club or an
actual business partner, teaming up is a way

9.text: to supercharge your wealth building plan.

12.text:
There are a lot of reasons to partner with
someone - and many combinations - with the

18.text:
Partner A has money and Partner B has skills
Partner A an idea and Partner B knows how

23.text:
to get it done
Partner A & B are friends or family

28.text:
You will often hear that partnerships are
a bad idea and can ruin relationships - which

32.text: is all true - but I think it's a bit overblown.

36.text:
The key to a successful partnership is shared
values. It doesn't matter if one partner

41.text:
is paperwork-savvy and the other is a great
salesman, or if one has money and the other

46.text:
doesn't. What matters is that the partners
have the same life and business values.

52.text:
Let me share two partnership stories in my
own life: one very successful one and one

57.text:
that was successful, but strained a relationship
for a short time.

62.text:
Several years ago I partnered on a business
with a very close friend. I was partner A

67.text:
(I had the money) and he was partner B (he
knew how to get it done). What I learned was

73.text:
that even though we were great friends, we
were horrible business partners. I was a master

78.text:
delegator, and he was the do-it-yourselfer.
I wanted to hire people to help us with the

83.text:
work, and he wanted to assign every job to
himself. This, of course, created tension.

88.text:
You had one person doing 90% of the work - because
despite his values of doing everything himself,

94.text:
I refused to turn all of my available time
into work - when I preferred to hire out these

101.text:
duties. In the end, we both made money, so
the friendship continues to this day. Luckily,

107.text:
things didn't get ugly with a financial
loss, because you just never know how it could

113.text:
have gone. Blame and anger are easy to rise
up when times are bad and money is being lost.

120.text:
The most successful partnership in my life
and one that still reigns today will likely

130.text:
last for decades. Having problems, disagreements,
failure and frustration are all normal. Success,

137.text:
of course, helps. There are not too many complaints
when everyone is making money, but the real

143.text:
key to this partnership working is shared
values.

146.text:
We both have a real desire to build something
of legacy and the belief that a rising tide

151.text:
lifts all boats, meaning we reward everyone
who helps us, and, most importantly, have

156.text:
a clear goal that the business is designed
to give us the financial independence to focus

161.text:
on other things we enjoy doing. Other natural
characteristics help as well, like both of

167.text:
us being neither lazy nor workaholics. Each
of us has skill sets that help drive the business

175.text:
No matter what type of business you start
or investment you make - with or without a

180.text:
partner - the virtue of being able to move
on and learn from failure is also critical.

187.text:
As an entrepreneur, I can honestly tell you
that I fail more often than I am successful,

193.text:
so you can never let failure shut you down.
I've conditioned my brain to the point that

198.text:
failure is rarely regretted for more than
a minute or two. I try new ideas all the time

206.text:
and just move on without a second thought
if they don't work.

210.text:
Building a team to help you will also add
to the "getting rich is fun" part as well.

217.text:
Consider some of the people in your own life.
If none of them seem to be a match, go meet

222.text:
new people. A good business partnership can
be very rewarding, especially since it divides

228.text:
work duties, time and even real financial
risk.
